titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Holly Solomon Gallery Records, circa 1948-2003, in the Archives of American Art AAA.hollsolg
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Erin Kinhart, Caitlin Lampman, and Rachel Rosenfeld

note.p: This finding aid was created from a MARC collection-level record. 293606

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-09-17T15:41-0400

did.abstract: The records of Holly Solomon Gallery, a New York City gallery specializing in contemporary American art, measure 196.1 linear feet and date from circa 1948-2003. The gallery's activities are documented through dealer files, subject files, artists' files, inventories, sales and loan records, administrative and financial records, printed materials, photographic materials of artwork and exhibitions, sound, video, and film recordings, and scattered electronic records. Also found are records of the alternative space, 98 Greene Street Loft, as well as Holly Solomon's personal papers.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated in 2010 by Thomas and John Solomon, Holly Solomon's sons.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was minimally processed and a finding aid prepared by Erin Kinhart, Caitlin Lampman, and Rachel Rosenfeld in 2011.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Holly Solomon Gallery records, circa 1948-2003. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is access restricted. Use requires written permission. Financial and Legal Records (Series 8) are closed to researchers until they can be processed to a more detailed level.

userestrict.head: Ownership and Literary Rights
userestrict.p: The Holly Solomon Gallery records are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Holly Solomon Gallery was established in 1975 by Holly Solomon and her husband, Horace Solomon, at 392 West Broadway in New York City's SoHo area. The gallery focused on contemporary art.

The gallery represented artists such as William Wegman, Nam June Paik, Laurie Anderson, and Robert Kushner. In 1983, the gallery moved uptown to 724 Fifth Ave at 57th, but then moved again in the early 1990s back downtown to SoHo at 172 Mercer Street. After the gallery closed Holly Solomon continued to deal art from the Chelsea Hotel until her death in 2002.

Holly Solomon was born Hollis Dworken in Bridgeport, Connecticut in 1934. She started college at Vassar College, and later transferred to Sarah Lawrence College where she graduated in 1955. In 1953 she married Horace Solomon. Holly Solomon was an aspiring stage actress and was enrolled at Lee Strasberg's Actor's Studio shortly after moving to Manhattan. Although she was not a successful actress she and her husband began collecting art and were fans of the Pop Art movement. In 1969 the couple opened an alternative work and performance space for artists named 98 Greene Street Loft. The space provided a venue for poets, actors, and artists to work and perform. Solomon wrote and produced a five part documentary from performances at 98 Greene Street, and in 1972 it was shown at the Edinburgh International Film Festival. 98 Greene Street Loft closed in 1973. Holly Solomon was also a proponent of the Pattern and Decoration, or "P and D", art movement of the late 1970s and early 1980s. Many of the artists featured in her gallery were involved in the P and D movement including Robert Kushner, Kim MacConnel, Ned Smyth, and Brad Davis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The records of Holly Solomon Gallery, a New York City gallery specializing in contemporary American art, measure 196.1 linear feet and date from circa 1948-2003. The gallery's activities are documented through alphabetical files, dealer files, subject files, artists' files, inventories, sales and loan records, administrative and financial records, printed materials, photographic materials of artwork and exhibitions, sound, video, and film recordings, and scattered electronic records. Also found are records of the alternative space, 98 Greene Street Loft, as well as Holly Solomon's personal papers.

Alphabetical files span from 1991-2000 and contain correspondence with clients, galleries, and museums, as well as related documentation regarding loans, inquiries, sales, exhibitions, and travel plans. These general files were maintained separately from the gallery's subject and artists' files but may overlap in subject matter.

The dealer files contain gallery correspondence to and from art dealers regarding inquiries on works and artists. These files are sparse and particular to the early 1980s. Subject files are mainly comprised of correspondence but also include printed materials, slides, and other related documents. Subjects include dealers, organizations, museums, clients, art fairs, travel, and projects that the gallery or Holly Solomon worked with.

Artists' files consist of correspondence, printed material, slides, photographs, and scattered inventory records, regarding the sale of artwork, as well as shipping records and insurance claims. Also included is correspondence between the gallery and the artist. There is substantial documentation on artists Kim MacConnel, Nam June Paik, Izhar Patkin, William Wegman, and Joe Zucker. Inventory records include inventory lists created by Holly Solomon Gallery as well as an art inventory card file. Inventory cards note the title, date, and size of the work as well as the dates and movements of the work, and may include a photograph.

Administrative records contain general office materials such as phone messages books, staff notebooks, exhibition guest books, and business diaries, exhibition documentation, notes, and mail from prospective artists. Records primarily cover the 1980s and 1990s. In addition to business diaries, Holly Solomon also created "Dear Diary" binders which contain a collection of contact information and notes on clients and events. Some of these diaries were maintained for specific events.

Sales and loan records consist of in and out sheets, consignments, and sales invoices. Also in this series are sales and loan logs and files that track the same information but from different access points, including sales by artist. Financial records document the financial activities of the galleries, apart from sales, and include shipping records, tax and insurance information, and accounting statements and reports. Also found in this series are bills, receipts, and several ledgers. Legal records primarily document issues with the landlord of the gallery space.

Printed material consists of artist clippings, gallery exhibition catalogs, press releases, posters, and miscellaneous books, magazines, and clippings regarding the gallery. Included are clippings pertaining to the Pattern and Design art movement. Photographic material includes photographs and slides documenting artists' work and gallery exhibitions. Sound, video, and film recordings include artworks created by gallery artists, performances recorded live at the gallery, and the publicity Holly Solomon, the gallery and its artists received. The work of video artist Nam June Paik is highly represented through some of his video artworks, as well as television interviews with him. Prominent artists William Wegman and Laurie Anderson are also represented through original artworks and publicity. Publicity videos include Holly Solomon herself, being interviewed for television and documentaries.

The records of 98 Greene Street Loft include a large quantity of sound, video, and film recordings of poetry readings, live music, art, and theatrical performances that took place from 1971-1973, as well as scattered paper records such as play scripts, photographs, a guest book from 1971, printed material, and posters.

Holly Solomon's personal papers consist of biographical documents, correspondence, memorabilia, printed material, motion picture film, and photographs collected by Holly Solomon throughout her life. Included are school records, letters, notes and cards from friends and artists she represented at her gallery, photographs, invitations, event fliers, and other mementos. Printed material, mostly magazines and newspapers document her accomplishments.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 14 series:

list.item: Series 3: Subject Files, circa 1975-2002 (Boxes 11-25; 15.0 linear feet)
Series 4: Artists' Files, circa 1975-2002 (Boxes 26-47; 22.0 linear feet)
Series 6: Administrative Records, circa 1980-2003 (Boxes 67-81, OV 202; 15.1 linear feet)
Series 7: Sales and Loan Records, circa 1975-2001 (Boxes 82-87; 6.0 linear feet)
Series 8: Financial and Legal Records, circa 1969-2001 (Boxes 88-114, 191, 192; 27.7 linear feet)
Series 9: Printed Material, circa 1968-2002 (Boxes 115-135, 193-194, OV 203-222, RD 223; 23.5 linear feet)
Series 10: Photographic Material, circa 1969-2000 (Boxes 136-156, 194-196, 201, OV 224; 22.2 linear feet)
Series 11: 98 Greene Street Loft, circa 1969-1973 (Boxes 166-169, 197-200, OV 225-227; 5.5 linear feet)
Series 12: Holly Solomon Personal Papers, circa 1948-2002 (Boxes 170-182, 194; 13.1 linear feet)
Series 13: Sound, Video, and Film Recordings, circa 1966-2001 (Boxes 183-190; 7.6 linear feet)

arrangement.p: The collection has been minimally arranged into series based on the found arrangement upon receipt, assumed to be the original arrangement of the gallery. Folders have been arranged within series and general folder contents verified, but in most cases, item level arrangement has not been completed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The alphabetical files span from 1991-2000 and contain miscellaneous incoming and outgoing gallery correspondence with clients, galleries, and museums regarding loans, inquiries, sales, exhibitions, and travel plans. Some of the correspondence includes printed materials, slides, and other related documents. These files were maintained separately from the gallery's subject and artists' files for any correspondence that did not have enough bulk to warrant its own file. There may also be some overlap with Series 3: Subject Files and Series 4: Artists' Files for items that were accidentally filed in these general files instead of into the proper subject or artist file. Additional correspondence can also be found within the dealer files, administrative records, and financial and legal records.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Items are filed alphabetically by company name or last name. Within each letter of the alphabet, items were also filed by year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The dealer files contain gallery correspondence to and from art dealers regarding inquiries on works and artists. These files are sparse and particular to the early 1980s. For more dealer files researchers should review Series 3: Subject Files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Files are maintained in the original gallery arrangement, alphabetically by location of dealer (i.e., state, country, or region). Folder titles have been transcribed from the existing folder labels.

did.unittitle: American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The subject files are mainly comprised of correspondence but also include printed materials, slides, and other related documents. The files span the life of the gallery from 1975 to 2002. Subjects include dealers, organizations, museums, clients, art fairs, travel, and projects that the gallery or Holly Solomon worked with. Researchers should note that some artists' information is contained within this series, and these files should be consulted along with files in Series 4: Artists' Files. There is significant coverage on Holly Solomon's work with the Art Dealer's Association of America, as well as the gallery's participation in events like FIAC (International Contemporary Art Fair), and the gallery's relationship with Museum of Modern Art (MOMA.)

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged in alphabetical order by subject. Folder titles in this listing have been transcribed from the existing folder labels. For folders missing labels, titles were given based on the material in the file. Folder titles assigned by the archivist are indicated by brackets.

did.unittitle: American Academy of Arts and Letters
Aspen Center for the Visual Arts
First New York Bank for Business
Institute of Contemporary Art (University of Pennsylvania)
Kunsthalle New York Project - Martin Kunz, Director
National Museum of Woman in the Arts
Usdan Center for the Creative and Performing Arts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The artists' files include correspondence to and from the gallery about the artist in regards to their works, in particular the sales and payment information of works, shipping records and any insurance claims. Any correspondence between the gallery and the artist is also included in these files. Additional materials found here include printed materials, slides, photographs, clippings, and scattered inventory cards. There is substantial documentation on artists Kim MacConnel, Nam June Paik, Izhar Patkin, William Wegman, and Joe Zucker. Researchers should note that additional documentation on artists may also be found throughout this collection, especially within Series 3: Subject Files, Series 5: Inventory Records, Series 9: Printed Material, and Series 10: Photographic Materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Files are in alphabetical order by artists' last name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains various inventory lists created by Holly Solomon Gallery as well as an art inventory card file. Inventory cards note the title, date, and size of the work as well as the dates and movements of the work. Some cards also include a Polaroid of the work of art. Researchers should note that scattered inventory cards may also be housed in Series 4: Artists' Files. The inventory cards span the life of the gallery, from 1975 to 2000. Inventory lists include print outs of the gallery inventory, logs kept to track works by artist, gallery checklists and stocklists, inventory lists for Holly Solomon Editions as well as inventories of Holly Solomon's personal collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The inventory cards are arranged alphabetical by artist's last name. Within an artist grouping the cards are in order by accession number.

did.unittitle: Holly Solomon Personal Collection Proposed Values
Master Inventory of Gallery Artists, Africano-Wegman

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Administrative records contain general office materials such as phone messages books, notebooks used by staff, exhibition guest books, and business diaries. Records primarily cover the 1980s and 1990s. Business diaries are in day calendar format and contain appointment, contact, and event information. Tucked and stapled into the books are business cards, invitations, announcements, and occasionally correspondence. Each diary is one calendar year and some years have more than one diary while other years are missing. Also found are diaries used only for Holly Solomon Editions; a Holly Solomon Editions stamp on the inside cover page designates the diary's use.

The "Dear Diary" files parallel the business diaries but are not specifically calendar oriented. These diaries were compiled in binders by Holly Solomon, arranged by month and year, and contain a collection of contact information and notes on clients and events. Some of the diaries were maintained for a specific event, such as the Armory Art Fair of 1999. Researchers should note that additional "Dear Diary" materials may be contained within specific event folders found in Series 3: Subject Files. Diary material has been removed from binders into archival folders, but the original order has been maintained.

Exhibition binders found in this series contain layout and artist information for exhibitions in the early 1980s. Also found are boxes of unsorted mail and other documents that were never filed, mail from artists seeking representation, artists' biographies, and a file of Holly's notes.

did.unittitle: Corporate Records Book: Holly Solomon Gallery Inc
Correspondence to Holly Solomon Gallery from Holly

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The sales and loan records consist of in and out sheets, consignments, and sales invoices. In and out sheets tracked works as they moved in and out of the gallery and are limited to the date span of 1994-2000. For similar information please see the card files in Series 5: Inventory Records. Invoice records are divided between works that were on consignment and those works which were not; invoices date from 1978-2001 while the consignment invoices date from 1978-2000. Also in this series are sales and loan logs and files that track the same information but from different search points, including sales by artist. Files regarding Holly Solomon Editions invoicing are labeled as such.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Invoices are arranged by invoice number in ascending numerical order, which also follows a chronological order. The invoices have three numbering sequences due to changes in invoicing practices in the gallery. Material has been removed from binders into archival folders, but the original order has been maintained.

did.unittitle: Consignment by Artist, Holly Solomon Editions
Consignment Invoices Nos. 767-1017, Holly Solomon Editions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains financial files maintained by the gallery, including shipping and trucking invoices and records, tax and insurance information, and accounting statements and reports. Also found in this series are unpaid and paid bills, check stubs, petty cash receipts, and several ledgers. One box of legal records documents issues with the landlord of the gallery space.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The financial files have been grouped together at the box level but are currently unprocessed.

did.unittitle: Paid Bills, F- New York Telephone

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of artist clippings, gallery exhibition catalogs, press releases, posters, and miscellaneous books, magazines, and clippings regarding the gallery. The artist clipping files contain exhibition announcements, newspaper clippings, magazine articles, and invitations to events. The quantity of material in these files varies greatly by artist. Artists such as Nicholas Africano, Laurie Anderson, Robert Kuchner, Gordon Matta-Clark, Judy Pfaff, and William Wegman have large quantities of material. Also found are clippings pertaining to the Pattern and Design art movement, exhibition catalogs and announcements, and a box of books Holly Solomon kept in her office.

Most of the posters in this series are for exhibitions for artists represented by Holly Solomon Gallery; however, posters for exhibitions put on by other galleries are included. Also found are posters artist Eric Drooker illustrated for local NYC causes and organizations.

did.unittitle: Holly Solomon Gallery Catalogs and Publications
Posters, ArtAttack Exhibition; Art Against Aids; Arch Connelly
Posters, Chryssa; The Lilja Collection; Matta-Clark, Gordon; Patkin, Izhar
Posters, Gray, Spaulding/Yourgrau, Barry; Roller-Wilson, Donald
Posters, Kushner, Robert; MacConnel, Kim; Miralda; Pfaff, Judy
Framed Print on Fabric, MacConnel, Kim

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographic material includes photographs and slides documenting artists' work and gallery exhibitions. Found here are black and white and color photographs, including many polaroids, arranged by artist or by subject. Photographs primarily depict artwork, artwork installed for a gallery exhibition, or gallery performances. This series contains very few photographs of artists. The amount of material found within these files is varied and researchers should note that some photographic material can also be found in files in Series 4: Artists' Files. While most slides are housed separately, photograph files may also include scattered slides, as well as negatives and transparencies. The majority of files are by artist, but there are also files of photographs by subject. Subjects include various exhibitions, gallery flood damage, and events. Of note are photographs from the opening of the gallery's first exhibition in 1975.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged as 2 subseries:

Photographs by artist and slides by artist are in alphabetical order by artists' last name. Among the photographs arranged by artist items may be arranged by year, exhibition, performance, or format, while other files have no particular arrangement. The slides series is arranged in three ways: in folders arranged alphabetically by artist, in binders alphabetically by artist, and in slide boxes by artist. The first set was marked as a duplicate set and most likely mimics what is in the alphabetical binders.

did.physdesc: (5 folders; see also oversized materials in boxes 195-196, OV 224)
(5 folders; see also oversized materials in boxes 195-196, OV 224)

did.unittitle: Whitney Museum of American Art Misc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Included in this series are sound, video, and film recordings of poetry readings, live music, art, and theatrical performances that took place from 1971-1973 at the 98 Greene Street Loft space. Unless otherwise indicated, recordings are literary readings given by the person listed, including video of the poets Joe Brainard, Jim Brodey, Michael Brownstein, Dick Gallup, Ted Greenwald, Maureen Owen, Charles Plymell, and Anne Waldman, among others. Most of the poetry readings were part of a series curated by the poet Ted Greenwald.

In addition to readings, there are recordings of a field trip to Gordon Matta-Clark's "Splitting" house, a Christmas concert featuring Taylor Mead, and a parish Christmas party featuring the artist Thomas Lanigan-Schmidt teaching children to make tin foil angels. Also found is 98.5, Holly Solomon's collaborative documentary made with Bert Spielvogel that highlights five artists from the 98 Greene Street Loft including Charles Simonds, Ed Baynard, Susan Hall, Gordon Matta-Clark, and George Schneemann. Paper records include a few play scripts, some photographs of artists and performances, a guest book from 1971, printed material, a storyboard for a segment of 98.5, and posters used to advertise the various performances and events taking place at the loft. Performance posters are cross-referenced with the performance recordings when possible. In addition to the posters, some of the original screens used to design the posters are included. Recordings are on 13 film reels (16mm), 31 video reels (1/2 inch), and 28 sound tape reels.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Sound, video, and film recordings are arranged in rough alphabetical order by performing artist. Where there was performance title present, it is listed first, then the artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Holly Solomon's personal papers consist of biographical documents, correspondence, memorabilia, printed material, motion picture film, and photographs collected by Holly Solomon throughout her life. The earliest materials include high school mementos and both her high school and college yearbooks, while later items include notes and cards from friends and artists she represented at her gallery. The boxes of personal correspondence, memorabilia and photographs are not sorted or organized any particular order. Included are postcards, telegrams, letters, photographs of friends and family, invitations, and event fliers.

Motion picture films include one short reel of black and white 16mm and a color Super 8mm (400 ft.) of Holly Solomon and others who are unidentified. Also found are three film reels (16mm, color) of a golfer. This series also includes legal documents regarding Solomon's 1990 divorce and a collection of printed material, mostly magazines and newspapers covering her accomplishments. The printed materials range from the 1950s through her death in 2002. The guest books from her 2002 memorial service at the Guggenheim are also included.

did.unittitle: Loose Items from an unused Scrapbook
Book, The Complete Works of William Shakespeare
Sarah Lawrence College Alumni Award Plaque
Matted Exhibtion Annoucement signed by Holly

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of recordings collected by the Holly Solomon Gallery. The content of the recordings are both about the gallery itself, and the artists it represented. The series is organized into artworks created by gallery artists, performances recorded live at the gallery, and the publicity Holly Solomon, the gallery and its artists received. The recordings range from before the gallery's opening in 1975 until after its closure in 2002, with most recordings coming out of the 80s and 90s. The work of video artist Nam June Paik is highly represented within the series through some of his actual video artworks, as well as through numerous documentaries and television interviews with him. Prominent artists William Wegman and Laurie Anderson are both represented through original artworks and publicity. Exhibition annoucements and gallery installation instructions accompany some of Anderson's sound cassettes used in her gallery shows. Also included are six empty cassette cases of hers with poems on the covers. Many of the publicity videos are of Holly Solomon herself, being interviewed for television and documentaries as early as 1989 for an episode of Art Market Report all the way up until just before her death in 2002 when she was profiled in a docuemntary about women art dealers called Off the Canvas. Recordings are on 164 videocassettes (136 VHS, 21 U-matic, 7 Betamax), 13 sound cassettes, 2 sound tape reels, and 1 sound disc.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Sound, video, and film recordings are arranged in rough alphabetical order by artist. Where there was no artist name listed, the title was used if present.

unittitle.emph: The Electronic Super Highway, Nam June Paik in the 90s

did.unittitle: Various news reports on the work on Nam June Paik

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Various news reports and profiles from the national networks like CBS, NBC and CNN, and foreign networks like the BBC, KBS (Korean Broadcasting System), SBS (Seoul Broadcasting System). Also included is footage of Paik meeting President Bill Clinton in 1998.)
